discussion.p: Generally, basic_string has a constructor matching each assign function and vice versa (except the constructor takes an allocator where assign does not). P0254R2 violates this by adding an assign(basic_string_view, size_type pos, size_type n = npos) but no corresponding constructor.

Robert Douglas provides initial wording.
We decided against another constructor overload to avoid the semantic confusion between:

blockquote.pre: basic_string(char const*, size_type length, Allocator = Allocator())
template<class T, class Foo = is_convertible_v<T const&, basic_string_view<charT, traits>> basic_string(T const&, size_type pos, Allocator = Allocator())

discussion.p: and instead get "Hello". The second parameter changes between length and position.
Fri PM: Move to Tentatively Ready

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4606.

li.p: In add the following constructor overload:
In add the following ctor definition:

pre.ins: template<class T> basic_string(const T& t, size_type pos, size_type n, const Allocator& a = Allocator());

p.ins: -?- Effects: Creates a variable, sv, as if by basic_string_view<charT, traits> sv = t; and then behaves the same as:
-?- Remarks: This constructor shall not participate in overload resolution unless is_convertible_v<const T&, basic_string_view<charT, traits>> is true.
